data.title: PEDEVCO Files 8K - Operations And Financial Condition >PED
data.description:
PEDEVCO Corp. (PED) filed a Form 8K - Operations and Financial Condition - with the U.S Securities and Exchange Commission on February 04, 2025.

The matters set forth in, or incorporated by reference in, Item 7.01 or Item 8.01 , to the extent they relate to results of operations and financial condition of PEDEVCO Corp. (the "Company"), for a completed quarterly or annual fiscal period, are incorporated by reference in this Item 2.02

The full text of this SEC filing can be retrieved at: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1141197/000165495425001154/ped_8k.htm

Any exhibits and associated documents for this SEC filing can be retrieved at: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1141197/000165495425001154/0001654954-25-001154-index.htm

Public companies must file a Form 8-K, or current report, with the SEC generally within four days of any event that could materially affect a company's financial position or the value of its shares.

data.title: Premier, Inc. SEC 10-Q Report
data.description:
Premier, Inc., a leading healthcare improvement company, has released its Form 10-Q report for the second quarter of fiscal year 2024. The report highlights significant financial and operational challenges faced by the company, particularly in its Supply Chain Services and Performance Services segments. Despite these hurdles, Premier, Inc. remains focused on strategic adjustments and future growth opportunities within the U.S. healthcare market.

Financial Highlights

  • Net Revenue: $240.3 million, decreased by 14% compared to the same period last year, reflecting challenges in both Supply Chain Services and Performance Services.
  • Gross Profit: $171.2 million, indicating a decline from the previous year, primarily due to increased operating expenses.
  • Operating (Loss) Income: $(92.8) million, a significant decrease from the previous year's income, driven by higher selling, general, and administrative expenses.
  • Net (Loss) Income from Continuing Operations: $(45.8) million, compared to a net income of $50.4 million in the prior year, impacted by increased costs and impairment charges.
  • Net (Loss) Income: $(85.2) million, reflecting losses from both continuing and discontinued operations.
  • Basic (Loss) Earnings Per Share from Continuing Operations: $(0.60), compared to $0.43 in the prior year, highlighting the impact of increased expenses and impairment charges.
  • Diluted (Loss) Earnings Per Share from Continuing Operations: $(0.60), consistent with basic EPS, due to the anti-dilutive effect of potential shares.

Business Highlights

  • Revenue Segments: The Supply Chain Services segment, which includes the company's GPO and Remitra, reported a decrease in net revenue by 11% for the three months ended December 31, 2024, compared to the same period in 2023. The Performance Services segment, which includes PINC AI and Contigo Health, saw a 19% decline in net revenue for the same period.
  • Geographical Performance: The company does not have significant foreign operations or revenues, focusing primarily on the U.S. healthcare market.
  • Future Outlook: The company anticipates increased demand for its Supply Chain Services and Performance Services solutions due to trends in cost management, quality and safety, and value-based care. However, uncertainties such as inflation, geopolitical tensions, and healthcare legislation could impact these expectations.
  • Strategic Review: The company concluded its exploration of strategic alternatives, resulting in the divestiture of its direct sourcing subsidiary, S2S Global, to Prestige Ameritech, Ltd., and the sale of certain assets of Contigo Health's wrap network business.
  • Operational Adjustments: The company has integrated Remitra into the Supply Chain Services segment to better align with its strategic goals and operations.
  • Market Trends: The company is monitoring the impact of inflation, labor costs, and geopolitical tensions on its operations and the broader healthcare market, which could affect supplier pricing and member demand.

SEC Filing: Premier, Inc. [ PINC ] - 10-Q - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: MERCURY SYSTEMS INC SEC 10-Q Report
data.description:
Mercury Systems Inc., a leading technology company specializing in defense and aerospace solutions, has released its Form 10-Q report for the second quarter ended December 27, 2024. The report highlights significant improvements in financial performance and outlines key operational strategies and achievements.

Financial Highlights

Net Revenues: Mercury Systems reported net revenues of $223.1 million for the second quarter, marking an increase from $197.5 million in the same period of the previous year. This growth was driven by higher sales in both domestic and international markets.

Gross Margin: The company's gross margin improved to $60.8 million, up from $31.5 million in the same period last year, reflecting better cost management and operational efficiency.

Loss from Operations: Mercury Systems reported a loss from operations of $(12.4) million, a significant improvement from the $(53.9) million loss recorded in the same period of the previous year. This was primarily due to reduced operating expenses.

Net Loss: The net loss for the second quarter was $(17.6) million, compared to a net loss of $(45.6) million in the same period last year, indicating better overall financial performance.

Basic Net Loss Per Share: The basic net loss per share was $(0.30), compared to $(0.79) in the same period of the previous year, showing a reduction in loss per share.

Business Highlights

Revenue Segments: Mercury Systems reported revenue from three main product groupings: Components, Modules and Sub-assemblies, and Integrated Solutions. Integrated Solutions accounted for the largest share of revenue, indicating a strong demand for comprehensive system solutions.

Geographical Performance: The company saw significant revenue contributions from the U.S. and Europe, with the U.S. being the primary market. There was a notable increase in inter-geographic revenues, particularly between the U.S. and Europe, reflecting a growing international presence.

Customer Segments: Key customers included major defense contractors such as RTX Corporation and the U.S. Navy, which together accounted for a significant portion of the company's revenue. This highlights Mercury's strong position in the defense sector.

Operational Strategy: Mercury Systems continues to focus on leveraging its technological capabilities and expanding its program content through acquisitions. This strategy is aimed at enhancing its product offerings and increasing its market share in the defense and aerospace sectors.

Future Outlook: The company is committed to maintaining its technological edge by investing in critical capabilities and intellectual property. It plans to continue adapting commercial technology for aerospace and defense solutions, with a focus on emerging needs such as artificial intelligence.

Employee and Talent Management: As of December 27, 2024, Mercury Systems employed 2,374 individuals, with a strong emphasis on engineering and research and development. The company prioritizes talent attraction and retention to support its long-term strategic goals.

Product and Market Focus: Mercury's products are designed to meet the demands of compute-intensive applications in harsh environments, with a focus on sensor processing, electronic warfare, and C4I applications. This positions the company well to address the needs of defense and commercial customers.

SEC Filing: MERCURY SYSTEMS INC [ MRCY ] - 10-Q - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: InnovAge Holding Corp. SEC 10-Q Report
data.description:
InnovAge Holding Corp., a leading provider of the Program of All-Inclusive Care for the Elderly (PACE), has released its Form 10-Q report for the fourth quarter of 2024. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance and operational highlights, reflecting both the challenges and growth opportunities faced by the company in the healthcare sector.

Financial Highlights

Total Revenues: InnovAge reported total revenues of $208.999 million for the three months ended December 31, 2024, marking an increase from $188.898 million in the same period of 2023. This growth was primarily driven by an increase in capitation revenue.

Operating Loss: The company experienced an operating loss of $(12.556) million for the three months ended December 31, 2024, compared to $(1.785) million in the same period of 2023. The increased loss was mainly due to higher expenses, including impairment charges.

Net Loss: InnovAge reported a net loss of $(13.491) million for the three months ended December 31, 2024, compared to $(3.821) million in the same period of 2023. The higher net loss was influenced by increased operating expenses and impairment charges.

Net Loss Attributable to InnovAge Holding Corp.: The net loss attributable to InnovAge Holding Corp. was $(13.221) million for the three months ended December 31, 2024, compared to $(3.447) million in the same period of 2023.

Net Loss Per Share - Basic: The basic net loss per share was $(0.10) for the three months ended December 31, 2024, compared to $(0.03) in the same period of 2023.

Net Loss Per Share - Diluted: The diluted net loss per share was $(0.10) for the three months ended December 31, 2024, compared to $(0.03) in the same period of 2023.

Business Highlights

Revenue Segments: InnovAge operates primarily in the PACE segment, which is divided into East and West geographic divisions. The PACE segment is the main contributor to the company's revenue, with capitation revenue being the primary source.

Geographical Performance: The company operates 20 PACE centers across California, Colorado, Florida, New Mexico, Pennsylvania, and Virginia. The performance in these regions is influenced by local regulatory environments and market conditions.

Sales Units: As of December 31, 2024, InnovAge served approximately 7,480 PACE participants, making it the largest PACE provider in the United States based on participants served.

New Production Launches: The company has plans for new de novo centers in Downey and Bakersfield, California, although these are currently on hold due to regulatory reviews.

Future Outlook: InnovAge expects to continue experiencing elevated operating expenses due to increased salaries, wages, and benefits. However, it anticipates that its clinical and operational value initiatives will help offset these costs. The company is also focused on expanding its payer capabilities to better reflect the acuity of the populations it serves.

Operational Challenges: The company is facing challenges related to increased cost of care per participant, primarily due to higher wages and benefits. Additionally, there are delays in eligibility processing for new enrollments and Medicaid redetermination applications, particularly in California.

Labor Market Conditions: The healthcare sector is experiencing challenges in hiring due to increased demand for services and a limited supply of qualified professionals. This has led to wage pressures, particularly in California, where new legislation has increased minimum wages for healthcare workers.

Regulatory Compliance: InnovAge is focused on maintaining high quality of regulatory compliance across all its centers, which is critical for its operations and expansion plans.

SEC Filing: InnovAge Holding Corp. [ INNV ] - 10-Q - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: Mattel rises after upbeat annual profit forecast
data.description:
** Barbie parent Mattel's shares jump nearly 9% to $19.68 after market

** Toymaker forecasts 2025 profit above Wall Street expectations, beats holiday-quarter estimates

** Expects adj profit per share in the range of $1.66 to $1.72, vs est $1.58 - LSEG

** MAT says forecast takes into account potential impact of U.S. President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs on China, Mexico and Canada

** Company's Q4 net sales up 2% to $1.65 billion vs est of flat sales

** Posts adj earnings of 35 cents/shr vs est 20 cents/shr

** Stock fell 6% in 2024

data.title: Trump Turns Up the Heat on Federal Workers Ahead of Resignation Deadline — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Anita Hamilton

As a Feb. 6 deadline nears for federal employees to resign voluntarily with a soft exit, the Trump administration is tightening the screws in an effort to get firmer commitments from employees weighing the offer.

The initial email from the Office of Personnel Management that landed in workers' inboxes on Jan. 28 sounded almost too good to be true. Anyone who resigned by email was offered full pay through the end of September without ever having to set foot back in the office. "It really is a fair & generous offer," Tesla CEO Elon Musk, who is heading up President Donald Trump's sweeping cost-cutting efforts, posted on X the following day.

But it turns out that accepting the offer isn't quite as simple as typing "Resign" in a subject line, then hitting send. A template form for deferred-resignation agreements distributed to federal agencies this week requires employees to agree to new, more restrictive terms.

The biggest caveat is that while those accepting the offer are bound by it, the government is free to revoke it. A new OPM memo released Tuesday afternoon confirms this loophole, adding "Were the government to backtrack on its commitments, an employee would be entitled to request a rescission of his or her resignation." It doesn't state whether such a request would be honored.

Secondly, workers are still on the hook to keep working through the end of February before being placed on administrative leave. The Tuesday memo reiterated that ethical standards prohibiting outside employment might still apply through Sept. 30, but noted that "by minimizing an employee's job duties and limiting the number of matters in which he or she is involved, administrative leave reduces the potential for conflicts with any outside employment."

Lastly, the template agreement acknowledges the elephant in the room that many critics of the plan have pointed out: the government can't guarantee payment through the end of the fiscal year in September because it is only funded through March 14. If no funding deal is reached by then and the government shuts down, employees will be placed on furlough and then receive back pay once funding resumes.

Trump senior advisor Stephen Miller said on Friday that a "large number" of workers had already accepted the deal. The OPM declined Barron's request for hard numbers, saying they don't plan to share that information until after the Feb. 6 deadline.

As the clock ticks on the deferred-resignation offer, the government is also making things more uncomfortable for the more than one million federal civilian workers who currently either telework or have fully remote positions.

A Friday night memo to agency heads from the president sought to invalidate any collective-bargaining agreements that were executed in the last 30 days of the Biden administration. Because pre-existing remote work agreements were extended in new contracts for Education Department employees, for example, they might lose that perk. A Monday follow-up memo from OPM provides additional guidance on potentially revoking or renegotiating all existing telework arrangements.

It's unclear whether the administration can enforce such a policy, however, according to legal experts. In invoking a 2010 case decided by the Supreme Court to justify revoking agreements finalized shortly before taking office, "this policy like several others if effectuated will likely find itself determined by the courts as to its lawfulness," George Washington University law professor Aram Gavoor told Barron's. "The courts have the final say," he added.

It may have more leverage renegotiating telework arrangements. "The Administration can certainly direct agencies to revise those telework plans, and for some agencies conditions might justify a substantial reduction," said Georgetown Law professor David Super.

Federal law actually requires agencies to have telework plans, he adds. "But that statute, like those on rescissions, federal worker buy-outs, and collective bargaining, requires consideration of the particular circumstances of individual agencies."

Several unions representing federal workers, lawmakers including Virginia Democrat Sen. Tim Kaine, and Democratic Attorneys General from 12 states have all urged workers to either reject or use caution when weighing the offers. "These supposed offers are not guaranteed," said New York Attorney General Letitia James.

"Union contracts are enforceable by law, and the president doesn't have the authority to make unilateral changes to those agreements," union leader and president of the American Federation of Government Employees, Everett Kelley, said. "AFGE members will not be intimidated. If our contracts are violated, we will aggressively defend them."

But the abrupt firings or placement on administrative leave of workers in agencies including the Justice Department, Education Department, and U.S. Agency for International Development present a bleak alternative to those who don't take the offer and attempt to resist the new administration's policies.

Such fears may explain why the government is expecting a spike in last-minute resignations in the final hours before the Thursday deadline.

Write to Anita Hamilton at anita.hamilton@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: New Zealand Unemployment Rate Rises to 5.1% in December 2024 Quarter, Seen Highest Since September 2020
data.description:
New Zealand's unemployment rate jumped to 5.1% in the December 2024 quarter from 4.8% in the preceding three-month period, Stats NZ data showed Wednesday.

This was the highest rate since the September 2020 quarter. The consensus forecast was for a 5.1% print, according to Trading Economics.

The employment rate fell to 67.4% from a revised reading of 67.7% in the prior period. Notably, the annual fall in the employment rate last quarter reflected 32,000 fewer employed people compared with the December 2023 quarter's rate of 69%, per the report.

"This was the largest annual fall in employment since the year to the December 2009 quarter," labor market spokesperson Deb Brunning said.

The underutilization rate, which measures untapped capacity in the labor market, rose to 12.1% from 11.6%.

The annual wage inflation eased to 3.3% from the prior quarter's 3.8%. Average ordinary time hourly earnings rose 4.2% to NZ$42.57.

data.title: Match Group Q4 Earnings, Revenue Decline; Sets 2025, Q1 Outlook -- Shares Fall After Hours
data.description:
Match Group reported Q4 earnings late Tuesday of $0.59 per diluted share, down from $0.81 a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $0.55.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was $860.2 million, down from $866.2 million a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $857.1 million.

The company said it expects Q1 revenue of $820 million to $830 million. Analysts polled by FactSet expect $852 million.

For 2025, the company projects revenue of $3.38 billion to $3.50 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet expect $3.49 billion.

Match said its board maintained a quarterly dividend of $0.19 per share, payable April 17 to stockholders of record as of April 3.

Shares of the company fell about 8% in recent after-hours activity.

data.title: News Highlights: Top Global Markets News of the Day - Tuesday at 5 PM ET
data.description:
Stocks Recover Despite China Tariff Fears

A call between Trump and Xi Jinping hasn't happened Tuesday, but might come Wednesday.

Beijing's Retaliation Intensifies Trade War With U.S.

China's tariff increases and other countermeasures were mostly symbolic and apparently designed to project strength while leaving the door open to talks.

Fed's Daly Is in No Rush to Cut Interest Rates

The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco said she sees a strong U.S. economy.

Fewer Americans Are Quitting Their Jobs

The number of workers who left their jobs last year hit the lowest level since 2020, according to the Labor Department.

How U.S. Agriculture Market Is Approaching Tariffs and a Potential Trade War

Traders and farmers hope that the Trump administration is using tariff threats as leverage in trade negotiations, as opposed to following through with a major disruption to agricultural trade.

The U.K. Has Dodged Trump's Tariffs So Far. Here Are Some (Very British) Reasons Why.

In his global tariff offensive, President Trump has said trade with the U.K., while out of line, can be worked out.

Antitrust Shouldn't Become Trade War Weapon, EU Says

Competition enforcement is not a tool to be used in trade disputes, the European Commission said after U.S. tariffs triggered a tit-for-tat reaction from China.

RFK Jr. Clears Committee Vote, Is On Track to Become Health Secretary

Next, the full Senate will vote whether to confirm Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

Are Markets Underestimating the Tariff Problem?

Investors who see President Trump's new trade war as more bark than bite have so far been proven right. This could be a problem.

A U.S.-EU Trade War Would Threaten World's Richest Economic Relationship

European leaders call for cooperation with Trump but say they are ready to fight.

data.title: News Highlights: Top Company News of the Day - Tuesday at 5 PM ET
data.description:
Google's Revenue Growth Slows, Sending Shares Down

The tech giant's fast-growing cloud-computing business decelerated last quarter.

Chipotle's stock sinks after earnings, as sales trends disappoint investors

Some analysts said tougher comparisons, harsher weather and holiday timing may have put pressure on the fast-casual chain's recent sales.

AMD comes up short in a key segment - and that's pressuring its stock

While AMD's PC business beat expectations, its data-center business, which includes AI accelerators, missed the mark.

Mattel Relying on Supply Chain, Potential Price Increases to Offset Tariff Impacts

Chief Executive Ynon Kreiz said the company has spent years building out a supply chain that isn't overly reliant upon any one country. It will also consider increasing its prices, he said.

KKR Raises Its Direct Stakes in Three Companies

The firm said it would increase its investment in the companies by $1.1 billion in total as part of its unusual strategy of taking long-term stakes in businesses it likes.

Apollo Eyes 'Industrial Renaissance' After Investing Record $222 Billion Last Year

Apollo Global Management invested a firm record of $222 billion last year as the credit specialist sees increased opportunities to finance infrastructure developers in what it calls a "global industrial renaissance."

Merck Shares Hit After Guidance Falls Short, Gardasil Challenge

The drugmaker's guidance was affected by a pause in shipments of its top-selling vaccine to China from February through at least the middle of the year.

Pfizer Falls on RFK's Progress Towards Confirmation Despite Good Earnings. Its CEO is Unbothered.

CEO Albert Bourla says Pfizer has met the strategic goals it had set for itself in 2024, and that it was 'executing transformative changes.'

Okta to Cut 3% of Workforce to Reallocate Resources Toward Growth Priorities

The digital identity verification provider will recognize $11 million in restructuring charges during the fourth quarter, which will primarily be paid in the first quarter of fiscal 2026.

Wells Fargo clears another postscandal regulatory hurdle - but more remain

The bank's stock rises as it fulfills two disciplinary orders from the Federal Reserve related to its mortgage business - but five more remain, including its asset cap.

data.title: China Retaliates Against U.S. Tariffs. Trump-Xi Phone Call Expected. — Barrons.com
data.description:
Brian Swint and Callum Keown

President Donald Trump's decision to impose additional 10% tariffs on goods imported from China provoked an immediate response from the world's second-largest economy.

The new U.S. levies took effect overnight, prompting China to announce taxes of 10% on crude oil, and some machinery and cars imported from the U.S., plus 15% tariffs on coal and liquified natural gas products. China's tariffs will take effect next Monday.

The U.S. announced its tariffs on China, Mexico, and Canada over the weekend, citing the threat of the flow of illegal migrants and drugs, specifically fentanyl, from the countries. On Monday, Trump delayed his plans to impose tariffs on Mexico and Canada for at least one month after the countries agreed to secure their borders with the U.S. The question now is whether the U.S. and China can work out a similar deal to prevent the trade war from escalating further.

Trump is expected to speak with China's President Xi Jinping by phone. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters earlier Tuesday that the call will happen "soon," and Trump told reporters later on Tuesday that it would happen at an appropriate time. "I'm in no rush, " he said.

Julian Evans-Pritchard, the head of China economics at Capital Economics, said the tariffs could be postponed or canceled before they come into effect on Feb. 10. "For the most part, these moves are warnings that China intends to harm U.S. interests if need be but still give China the option to back down."

Evans-Pritchard also noted that the Chinese retaliation only targets about $20 billion worth of imports, compared to the $450 billion in Chinese wares that Trump has targeted. What's more, China didn't raise tariffs on strategic goods such as semiconductors and pharmaceuticals.

In a move that wasn't explicitly tied to Trump's tariffs, China also said it was starting an antitrust probe into Alphabet's Google, the internet search engine.

Beijing added two U.S. companies to its unreliable entity list — Calvin Klein owner PVH, and biotechnology company Illumina.

"The two entities have violated normal market-trading principles, terminated regular trade with Chinese companies, and adopted discriminatory measures against Chinese companies," state-owned news agency Xinhua reported, citing a statement from the Commerce Ministry.

The ministry said the list only targets the very few foreign entities that undermine China's national security. It means measures could be taken against the companies.

PVH told Barron's the company is "surprised and deeply disappointed" by the decision.

China also announced export controls on scarce elements that are critical for making electronics, including tungsten, tellurium, bismuth, molybdenum, and indium. China is a big miner of these materials.

Corrections & Amplifications: China plans to impose 10% tariffs on U.S. crude oil, machinery, and some cars, plus 15% tariffs on coal and liquefied natural gas products. A previous version of this article incorrectly stated the goods affected by the 10% and 15% tariffs.

Write to Brian Swint at brian.swint@barrons.com and Callum Keown at callum.keown@dowjones.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Australian Company Profit Margins Can Improve From Here — Market Talk
data.description: Profit margins of Australian companies have probably already troughed at mid-cycle levels, UBS says. Many of Australia's biggest listed companies will report earnings this month, giving investors the chance to do a pulse check on trading conditions. Strategist Richard Schellbach highlights prior concerns about companies' ability to maintain profit margins. But these concerns were unfounded, UBS says, as management was able to pass costs on to their customers. "The latest monthly data points still show business selling prices moving commensurately with their input costs," UBS says. And with the unemployment rate remaining low over the past six months, "this dynamic of being able to pass through costs remains favorable in most industries," UBS adds. (david.winning@wsj.com; @dwinningWSJ)

data.title: Mapletree Industrial Trust Issues 758,874 Units for Manager's Fee
data.description:
Mapletree Industrial Trust issued 758,874 new units at SG$2.2003 each to its manager as base fee payment, according to a Tuesday filing on the Singapore Exchange.

The issuance covers fees for 29 US data centers acquired in 2021 and a Japan facility added in 2023. The manager now holds 30.40 million units in the company, while total outstanding units stands at 2.85 billion.

data.title: Goodyear Tire Reaches Deal With Union to Cut 850 Jobs Amid Turnaround
data.description:
By Sabela Ojea

Goodyear Tire & Rubber is cutting 850 positions at its tire manufacturing facility in Danville, Va. as part of a wider plan to reduce production capacity and costs per tire in the Americas.

The Akron, Ohio-based tire-maker on Tuesday said that the reduction in the workforce, which affects associates and contracted workers, follows an agreement with the United Steelworkers union.

The Danville plant will continue to produce aviation tires and conduct mixing operations, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

Overall, Goodyear Tire & Rubber expects the cuts to be substantially completed by the end of the year. It also forecasts total pre-tax costs associated with the plan in the range of $130 million to $140 million.

The company expects to record about $100 million of these charges in the first quarter, and $40 million throughout the reminder of 2025.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber is expected to post fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday. In the latest quarter, the company posted a 6.2% drop in sales to $4.82 billion after seeing its tire unit volumes down around 8%, and raised its expectations for cost savings under a turnaround plan.

The company then said it was targeting gross run-rate gains from its Goodyear Forward program, announced in November 2023, of $1.5 billion by the end of 2025. The company's original target was $1.3 billion in run-rate benefits.

Write to Sabela Ojea at sabela.ojea@wsj.com; @sabelaojeaguix

data.title: HAMMER FIBER OPTICS HOLDINGS CORP SEC 10-K Report
data.description:
Hammer Fiber Optics Holdings Corp, a company focused on financial services technology and wireless telecommunications infrastructure, has released its annual 10-K report. The report provides a comprehensive overview of the company's financial performance, business operations, strategic initiatives, and the challenges it faces as it transitions towards a fintech-centric business model.

Financial Highlights

  • Revenues: $3.28 million, an increase of approximately $23,335 or 0.7% from the previous year, primarily due to the expansion of the Company's Over-the-Top ('OTT') business segment.
  • Gross Margin: $881,279, reflecting an improvement from the previous year due to cost management and revenue growth.
  • Loss from Operations: $(1.39) million, indicating an increase in operating expenses due to diversification into financial services and expansion of telecommunications.
  • Net Loss: $(1.23) million, a decrease from the previous year's loss of $(2.58) million, attributed to reduced other expenses and selling, general, and administrative expenses.
  • Basic and Diluted Loss Per Share: $(0.02), showing an improvement from the previous year's $(0.04) per share.

Business Highlights

  • Corporate History and Background: Hammer Technology Holdings Corp, originally incorporated as Recursos Montana S.A. in 2010, has undergone several transformations, including mergers and acquisitions, to focus on financial services technology and wireless telecommunications infrastructure.
  • Current Operations: The company is now focused on sustainable shareholder value through investments in financial services technology and wireless telecommunications infrastructure. Its financial technologies business is centered around the HammerPay mobile payments platform, which facilitates digital commerce in developing markets.
  • Telecommunications Strategy: Hammer's telecommunications strategy, branded as 'Everything Wireless', includes the development of high-speed fixed wireless services for various client segments using its Hammer Wireless AIR® platform, along with mobility networks and Over-the-Top services.
  • Discontinued Operations: The company has discontinued operations of Hammer Wireless (SL) Limited in Sierra Leone and Open Data Centers LLC, reflecting a strategic shift away from certain telecommunications operations.
  • Divestiture of Telecommunications Assets: In 2024, Hammer Technology Holdings Corp sold its telecommunications assets, including 1st Point Communications LLC and its subsidiaries, to Viper Networks, Inc., to focus on fintech initiatives.
  • Future Outlook: With the divestiture of telecommunications assets, the company is concentrating on its fintech initiatives, particularly the HammerPay platform, which is designed for global deployment in both developed and emerging markets.
  • Employee Structure: The company currently employs ten individuals, with six full-time and four part-time employees, indicating a lean operational structure.
  • Revenue Segments: The company's revenue growth is attributed to the expansion of its Over-the-Top business segment, which includes SMS messaging and hosting services.
  • Management's Discussion and Analysis: The management has highlighted the company's diversification into financial services markets and the expansion of its telecommunications business segment as key drivers of increased operating expenses.

Strategic Initiatives

  • Strategic Initiatives: Hammer Technology Holdings Corp. has focused on divesting its telecommunications assets to Viper Networks, Inc., which includes 1st Point Communications LLC and its subsidiaries, Endstream Communications LLC, American Networks Inc., and a 10% ownership in Wikibuli Inc. This strategic move allows the company to concentrate its efforts on its fintech initiatives, particularly the HammerPay platform, which is designed for global deployment in both developed and emerging markets.
  • Capital Management: The company has been actively managing its capital through various financing activities. It has relied on convertible notes and related party loans to finance operations. Notably, the company entered into a loan agreement with a board member for $791,546 to pay off a promissory note to Mast Hill Fund L.P. Additionally, the company has issued shares as part of its financing strategy, including 475,000 shares related to the Mast Note amendment. The company has not paid any dividends and does not plan to in the foreseeable future, opting instead to reinvest earnings into business operations.
  • Future Outlook: Looking ahead, Hammer Technology Holdings Corp. plans to continue focusing on its fintech initiatives, leveraging the HammerPay platform to drive growth. The company intends to rely on equity sales to fund operations and development activities, acknowledging the potential for shareholder dilution. The company also aims to address its going concern status by seeking additional capital through debt and equity financing until it achieves sustainable revenue generation.

Challenges and Risks

  • Market Risks: The rapidly changing technology landscape and evolving industry standards could adversely affect the company's ability to compete and succeed. Economic downturns and market declines could also harm the business.
  • Operational Risks: The company is dependent on its ability to develop new products and secure adequate spectrum for service deployment. Additionally, the violation of labor laws by manufacturers and suppliers could disrupt operations and damage the company's reputation.
  • Regulatory Risks: Compliance with changing regulations related to corporate governance and public disclosure increases operational costs and the risk of noncompliance.
  • Financial Risks: There is substantial doubt about the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to consistent losses and reliance on external financing.
  • Security Risks: The company is vulnerable to IT system disruptions and data breaches, which could lead to competitive harm and legal liabilities.
  • Management's Discussion and Analysis: The company has identified several challenges in its financial condition and results of operations, including the need for additional financing to address the working capital deficit and accumulated losses, highlighting the risk of remaining a going concern.

SEC Filing: HAMMER FIBER OPTICS HOLDINGS CORP [ HMMR ] - 10-K - Feb. 04, 2025

data.title: Colombia central bank revises up 2025 inflation outlook to 4.1%, from previous 3.1%
data.description:
The technical team of Colombia's central bank hiked its inflation forecast for this year to 4.1%, from a previous estimate of 3.1%, it said in a quarterly report published on Tuesday.

The new estimate - greater than the central bank's long-term inflation goal of 3% - comes amid greater pressure on prices due to expectations the Colombian peso will depreciate against the dollar, as well as a sharp 9.54% increase to the Colombian minimum wage this year.

The technical team - whose considerations are taken into account by the central bank's board members ahead of monetary policy decisions - forecast inflation to close 2026 at 3%.

"In 2025 and 2026 total inflation will continue its process of converging toward the target, though more slowly that predicted in (the previous report) in October," the report said, adding slower convergence would be due to increases in the minimum wage, external fiscal context pushing the exchange rate upward, among other factors.

According to the median of a recent Reuters poll, the central bank could lower its benchmark rate to close 2025 at 7%, before making further cuts in 2026 to bring it to 6%.

Uncertainty about inflation and the country's fiscal outlook led the monetary policy authority to hold the rate stable at 9.50% last week, the first pause in its cycle of cuts that began in December 2023.

During that meeting, bank board chief Leonardo Villar said the technical team had cut its economic growth forecast for 2024 to 1.8%, from a previous 1.9%, and revised its estimate for this year to 2.6%, compared to a previous estimate of 2.9%.

data.title: Voya Financial Q4 Adjusted Operating Earnings Fall, Revenue Increases
data.description:
Voya Financial reported Q4 adjusted operating earnings Tuesday of $1.40 per diluted share, down from $1.63 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $0.72.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was $2.01 billion, up from $1.82 billion a year earlier.

Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $1.89 billion.

Shares of Voya Financial surged nearly 7% in after-hours trading.

data.title: Groupe Dynamite Brief: Announcing comparable store sales growth of 9.5% For Q4 2024 and comparable store sales growth of 12.3% for the full fiscal year
FMC Q4 Adjusted Earnings, Revenue Rise; 2025 Outlook Issued -- Shares Tumble After Hours
data.description:
FMC reported Q4 adjusted earnings late Tuesday of $1.79 per diluted share, up from $1.07 a year earlier.

Analysts polled by FactSet expected $1.60.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec.31 was $1.22 billion, up from $1.15 billion a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $1.32 billion.

The company expects Q1 adjusted EPS of $0.05 to $0.15 on revenue of $750 million to $800 million. Analysts expect EPS of $0.77 on revenue of $957.4 million.

FMC also said that it expects full-year 2025 adjusted EPS of $3.26 to $3.70 on revenue between $4.15 billion and $4.35 billion. Analysts expect EPS of $4.35 on revenue of $4.39 billion.

Shares of the company tumbled about 16% in recent after-hours trading.

data.title: Australia's Private Sector Continues Modest Expansion for Fourth Straight Month
data.description:
The S&P Global Flash Australia PMI Composite Output Index increased to 51.1 in January from 50.2 in December, indicating modest growth in Australia's private sector activity.

Both manufacturing and services sectors experienced output growth for the first time since late 2022, with manufacturing returning to expansion.

New order growth remained strong in the services sector, although manufacturing saw a decline in new orders.

Employment rose again, and inflationary pressures also picked up during the month.

data.title: FMC Corp forecasts first-quarter revenue below estimates, shares dive
data.description:
Agrichemicals producer FMC Corp forecast first-quarter revenue below Wall Street estimates on Tuesday, owing to weak demand, sending its shares down over 20% in after-market trading.

The company's sales volume is expected to be lower as customers in various countries continue to reduce inventory and purchases are made cautiously by retailers and growers amid lower commodity prices, the company said.

High inventory levels of crop chemicals in multiple regions have been putting pressure on the earnings of insecticide and fungicide producers such as FMC.

FMC is one of the largest crop-protection product makers in the United States and competes with industry giants such as Syngenta, as well as German firms BASF and Bayer in the agricultural chemicals sector.

The company, however, beat Wall Street's fourth-quarter profit expectations, helped by higher sales volumes, especially in the United States, and lower costs.

"While we saw a good increase in volume, the growth was below our expectations as we learned during the quarter that customers in many countries sought to hold significantly less inventory than they have historically. This dynamic, along with more pronounced FX impacts, acted as a headwind to further growth," CEO Pierre Brondeau said in a statement.

The herbicide maker forecast first-quarter 2025 revenue in the range of $750 million to $800 million. Analysts' expectations were of $963.7 million.

First-quarter adjusted earnings are expected to be in the range of $0.05 to $0.15 per share, compared to estimates of $0.83 per share.

The Philadelphia-based company posted an adjusted profit of $1.79 cents per share for the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with analysts' average estimate of $1.6 cents per share, according to data compiled by LSEG.

data.title: Market Chatter: Westpac Banking Invests AU$10 Million in Lawpath to Grow Small Business Lending
data.description:
Westpac Banking has made an AU$10 million investment in legal services provider Lawpath to give its customers basic legal services for a year as part of its strategy to grow its small business lending, the Australian Financial Review reported Tuesday.

The deal will provide customers with a year-long subscription to access an archive of legal documents and business registration services, the report added. Lawpath will direct its customers to Westpac when they register.

Westpac Banking and Lawpath did not immediately respond to MT Newswires' request for comment.

(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)

data.title: New Zealand jobless rate rises to 5.1% in fourth quarter
data.description:
New Zealand's jobless rate rose to 5.1% in the fourth quarter, while employment fell 0.1% from the previous quarter, according to data released by Statistics New Zealand on Wednesday.

Economists polled by Reuters had forecast an unemployment rate of 5.1% and for employment to fall 0.2%. The central bank had also expected the unemployment rate to be 5.1%.

The participation rate was 71.0% in the fourth quarter. It was slightly lower than a forecast 71.1% participation rate.

“Unemployment has been increasing since late 2022. The unemployment rate in the December 2024 quarter was the highest it’s been since the September 2020 quarter,” said Statistics New Zealand labour market spokesperson Deb Brunning.

Wage growth remained unchanged in the quarter, with the private sector labour cost index (LCI) excluding overtime recording a 0.6% lift on the previous quarter, inline with forecasts.

An easing in tight labour market conditions and rising unemployment will firm the case for the central bank to cut the cash rate by 50 basis points when it meets in the middle of the month.

The central bank has cut the cash rate by 125 basis points since August and said in November that a further 50 basis point hike was likely in February amid cooling inflation pressures and a slowing economy.

data.title: H&R Block Fiscal Q2 Adjusted Loss Widens, Revenue Unchanged; 2025 Outlook Reaffirmed
data.description:
H&R Block reported a fiscal Q2 adjusted loss late Tuesday of $1.73 per diluted share, wider than a loss of $1.27 a year earlier.

Four analysts polled by FactSet expected a loss of $1.67.

Revenue for the quarter ended Dec. 31 was virtually unchanged at $179.1 million.

Three analysts surveyed by FactSet expected $182.1 million.

The company continues to expect fiscal year 2025 adjusted diluted earnings of $5.15 to $5.35. Four analysts surveyed by FactSet expect $5.29.

H&R Block also reaffirmed its revenue guidance for the year of $3.69 billion to $3.75 billion. Three analysts polled by FactSet expect $3.72 billion.

Shares of H&R Block were down 4.5% in recent after-hours activity.
